page.title: 05Whittlebury Ecology
page.content: It was proposed by the Nature Conservany Council to designate areas of parkland and woodland belonging to Whittlewood Forest as sites of Special Scientific Interest. The broad -leaved woods between Whittlebury and Potterspury are the most extensive, least-changed remnants of the once vast Crown coppices of Whittlewood Forest. They form a group of ancient semi-natural woodlands dating from the middle ages and earlier, typical of the midland clays. The variety of trees included are Oak, Ash, Silver Birch, Aspen and Elm. There is characteristic and diverse flora and fauna, including rare and uncommon species. The bird community includes species such as Woodcock, Redstart, Sparrow-hawk, Nuthatch, Green Woodpecker and Nightingale.
